lesson.title: Best Practices/Design Patterns for Kubernetes in Production
lesson.summary: In this lesson we'll learn some of the best practices for running your application in Kubernetes including logging, scale, and security

atoms.title: Kubernetes for Production Heading
atoms.text: ## Securing and Tuning Kubernetes Services for Production

atoms.title: ND9990 CDND C03 L05 A01 Kubernetes For Production V2
Lesson Outline
atoms.caption: What We Will Cover in The Lesson
atoms.alt: Our lesson goes over how to tune Kubernetes for production use.

atoms.title: Kubernetes for Production Summary
atoms.text:
Throughout this lesson, we will be going over some patterns and techniques for tuning Kubernetes services for production use.

We will cover:
- Configuring a Cluster
- Thinking About Production
- Reverse Proxy
-  Securing Microservices
- Scaling and Self-Healing
- Using Logs

atoms.title: Configuring a Cluster Heading
atoms.text: ## Configuring Your Cluster

atoms.title: ND9990 CDND C03 L05 A02 Configuring A Cluster V2
Configuring a Cluster Summary
atoms.text:
Kubernetes has configurations that can be tuned to optimize your deployed application.
### Cost
* Configure the resources and replicas for our deployed applications.

### Security
* Configure who has access to the Kubernetes pods and services.
* Secure traffic for least-privilege

question.prompt: What are the benefits of tuning your cluster?

answers.text: Reduce cost by utilizing cheaper hardware
Prevent malicious users from accessing your Kubernetes environment
Reduce development time by utilizing CI/CD

atoms.title: Thinking About Production  Heading
atoms.text: ## Thinking about Production

atoms.title: ND9990 CDND C03 L05 A03 Thinking About Production
Thinking About Production  Summary
atoms.text:
### Production-ready
Deployed applications for production-use are different than ones we use for development. We have to make additional considerations as the application is no longer running in our isolated environment.

#### Restrict Access
* Follow properties of least-privilege to secure our application.

#### Scale
* Be able to handle the number and size of user requests.

#### Availability
* Ensure that the application is responsive and able to be used when needed.

atoms.title: Restrict Access
atoms.caption: Use Least Privileged Access to Secure the Application

question.prompt: What are some ways the production environment differs from a development environment

question.title: Reflect
question.text: Load testing is a technique where we simulate multiple requests against our service. How can this be useful for helping us understand our code in production?

answer.text: Load testing is a common way to simulate a large number of requests to our application. By doing so, we are essentially stress-testing it to preview when it will fail. This helps us set a baseline understanding of the limits of our application.

atoms.title: Reverse Proxy Heading
atoms.text: ## Use a Reverse Proxy to Direct Backend Requests

atoms.title: ND9990 CDND C03 L05 A04 Part 1 How Reverse Proxies Work
Reverse Proxy
atoms.caption: A reverse proxy proxy is used to route traffic from one endpoint to multiple endpoints
atoms.alt: A reverse proxy proxy is used to route traffic from one endpoint to multiple endpoints.

atoms.title: Reverse Proxy Notes
RP screencast header
atoms.text: ## Setting up the Reverse Proxy

atoms.title: ND9990 CDND C03 L05 A04 Part 2 Setting Up The Reverse Proxy
RP demo code
atoms.text:
Here is the code I used in the demo:

***nginx.conf***
```
events {
}
http {
    server {
        listen 8080;
        location /api/ {
            proxy_pass http://my-app-2-svc:8080/;
        }
    }
}
```

***deployment.yaml***
``` 
apiVersion: extensions/v1beta1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
  labels:
    service: reverseproxy
  name: reverseproxy
spec:
  replicas: 1
  template:
    metadata:
      labels:
        service: reverseproxy
    spec:
      containers:
      - image: YOUR_DOCKER_HUB/simple-reverse-proxy
        name: reverseproxy
        imagePullPolicy: Always          
        resources:
          requests:
            memory: "64Mi"
            cpu: "250m"
          limits:
            memory: "1024Mi"
            cpu: "500m"       
        ports:
        - containerPort: 8080
      restartPolicy: Always
```

***service.yaml***
```
apiVersion: v1
kind: Service
metadata:
  labels:
    service: reverseproxy
  name: reverseproxy-svc
spec:
  ports:
  - name: "8080"
    port: 8080
    targetPort: 8080
  selector:
    service: reverseproxy
```

atoms.title: Deploying RP heading
atoms.text: ## Deploying the Reverse Proxy

atoms.title: ND9990 CDND C03 L05 A04 Part 3 Deploying The Reverse Proxy
Deploying RP recap
atoms.text:
### Commands
The commands that we use to deploy the reverse proxy are the same as that used to deploy the application. `kubectl` is used as our tool to interface with our cluster and the YAML file specifies the configuration for our reverse proxy.
* `kubectl apply <REVERSE_PROXY_DEPLOYMENT>.yaml`
* `kubectl apply <REVERSE_PROXY_SERVICE>.yaml`

Verifying RP Heading
atoms.text: ## Verifying Our Reverse Proxy

atoms.title: ND9990 CDND C03 L05 A06 Part 2 Verifying Reverse Proxy
Verifying RP Recap
atoms.text:
### Internal Communication
Our Kubernetes cluster is using a `ClusterIP` configuration. This means that the service is only exposed and visible to services inside of the cluster. 

Other services can access one another via the name of the service. In our case, it means that instead of having to use the IP address of `my-app-2-svc`, we can simply make requests to `my-app-2-svc`.

### Local Requests
As our service is not configured to accept requests outside of the service, we can’t communicate directly to the Kubernetes services. So far, we have been using `kubectl` to interact with the cluster on our behalf.

When verifying HTTP requests, we need to make them within the context of our Kubernetes cluster.

### Verifying Through Kubernetes
* `kubectl exec -it <POD_NAME> bash` of any pod to access the pod directly.
* `curl reverseproxy-svc:8080/api/health` to mimic an API request to the reverse proxy.

question.title: Reflect
question.text: Given a large organization, how may a dedicated team working on an API Gateway (type of reverse proxy) be beneficial from a technical and business perspective?

answer.text: An API Gateway can be considered its own business functionality. This will allow another team to work on its features in parallel to the services that it would route to. It would also reduce the responsibilities of individual teams by abstracting common logic that may be non-trivial to design and implement.

atoms.title: Securing Microservices Heading
atoms.text: ## Securing the Microservices

atoms.title: ND9990 CDND C03 L05 A07 Securing Microservices
Securing Microservices Notes
atoms.text:
This is not an all-inclusive list of things to do for securing your application. It means that while some of these are best-practice, there's no guarantee that these steps will ensure your application is perfectly secure.
* AWS security groups
Enables you to restrict the inbound and outbound traffic for AWS resources.
* Kubernetes Ingress and Egress
Enables you to restrict the inbound and outbound traffic for Kubernetes resources.

question.prompt: Given a microservice that is only interfaced through a reverse proxy, what is the best option to securing this microservice?

answers.text: Don’t set any restrictions on ingress traffic.
Set the microservice to allow ingress traffic from the reverse proxy and egress traffic from anywhere.
Set the microservice to only allow ingress traffic from the reverse proxy.
Set the microservice to only allow egress traffic from the reverse proxy.
Set the microservice to allow both egress and ingress traffic from the reverse proxy.

atoms.title: Scaling and Self-healing Heading
atoms.text: ## Configuring Scalable and Resilient Applications

atoms.title: ND9990 CDND C03 L05 A08 Scaling And Self-Healing V3
Self Healing Recap
atoms.text:
### Self-Healing
Kubernetes deployments can be set up to recover from failure.
* Health checks - an HTTP endpoint that must return a `200` response for a healthy status. Kubernetes will periodically ping this endpoint.
* Replicas - Kubernetes will attempt to maintain the number of desired replicas. If a pod is terminated, it will automatically recreate the pod.

atoms.title: Scaling header
atoms.text: ## Horizontal Scaling with Kubernetes

atoms.title: ND9990 CDND C03 L05 A08 Part 2 Horizontal Scaling In Kubernetes
Scaling and Self-healing Notes
atoms.text:
### Horizontal Pod Autoscaler
A deployment feature that allows additional pods to be created when a CPU usage threshold is reached.

#### Commands
* Create HPA
```
kubectl autoscale deployment <NAME> --cpu-percent=<CPU_PERCENTAGE>                --min=<MIN_REPLICAS>
--max=<MAX_REPLICAS>
```

* View HPA
```
kubectl get hpa
```

atoms.title: Scaling and Self-healing Heading New Terms
atoms.text:
### New Terms
| Term 	| Description 	|
|--------------------	|-----------------------	|
| Horizontal Pod Autoscaler (HPA) 	| A Kubernetes deployment feature that allows additional pods to be created when a CPU usage threshold is reached. 	|
| Liveness Probe 	| A monitoring activity that occurs at scheduled intervals to ping a health check API endpoint to validate that the application is in a healthy state.	|
| Resilience 	| The property of an application to handle and recover from failures. 	|

atoms.title: Scaling and Self-healing Further Research

The following are some additional resources for learning more about how we can make our deployed applications more robust:

atoms.title: Solution: Scaling and Self-healing Heading
atoms.text: ##  My Solution

atoms.title: ND9990 CDND C03 L05 A10 Solution Scaling And Self-Healing V2
Solution: Scaling and Self-healing Summary
atoms.text:
We can set up a Kubernetes HPA with the following command:
```
kubectl autoscale deployment <DEPLOYMENT_NAME> --cpu-percent=<DESIRED_THRESHOLD> --min=<MIN_PODS> --max=<MAX_PODS>
```
We can view the Kubernetes HPA with the following command:
```
kubectl get hpa
```
Note that for Kubernetes to be able to handle scaling our application, we will need sufficient Node Groups created in EKS.

atoms.title: Using Logs Heading
atoms.text: ## Use Logs to Capture Metrics for Debugging

atoms.title: ND9990 CDND C03 L05 A11 Using Logs
Using Logs Image
atoms.caption: Logs are important for helping us troubleshoot microservices
atoms.alt: Logs are important for helping us troubleshoot microservices.

atoms.title: Using Logs New Terms or Vocabulary
atoms.text:
### Key Points  

- Software is rarely free of errors so we need to troubleshoot errors when they occur. 

- In production environments we don't have tools like breakpoints that could help us identify bugs 

- Logging can get complicated so we need tools to handle logs and make it easy to search them.

- System logs used for debugging are sometimes different from error messages returned by API's.

### Strategies for Logging
* Use timestamps to know when the activity occurred
* Set a consistent style of logging to make it easier to parse log output
* Use process IDs to trace an activity
* Rotate logs so they don't fill up your storage
* Include stack traces in your logs
* Look at the delta in message timestamps to measure execution time

atoms.title: Using Logs Further Research
atoms.text:
### Additional Resources
For more resources on learning about logs:
* [Best Practices for Monitoring](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/monitoring_best_practices.html)
* [Netflix Scalable Logging and Tracking](https://netflixtechblog.com/scalable-logging-and-tracking-882bde0ddca2?gi=227c03a261e1)
* [Designing a Logging Strategy](https://docs.oracle.com/cd/E19424-01/820-4806/fyfcv/index.html)

concepts.text: Understand the time an event occurred.
Make it easier to ingest and parse errors
Prevents running out of disk space.

atoms.title: ND9990 CDND C03 L05 A12A Using Logs Exercise Solution Part 2
Using Logs Solution Summary
atoms.text:
We want to find the average of the 3 requests that were made. To identify the requests, we rely on the unique identifiers prepended to each message. Dividing the sum by the 3 requests will result in the average.

While this is a straightforward simulation, it serves to illustrate how logs can display a lot of similar output that are collected from a system that handles many concurrent requests.
